text: The sun was warm and bright. The town square was livelier than usual—children selling flowers, merchants shouting as the wind carried their voices away.
I sat on the wooden steps outside the inn, watching the fountain at the square’s center. The water shimmered in the sunlight, as if nothing had ever happened.
Alicia had changed into a simple light-colored dress, her silver hair tied loosely behind her—no armor, no sword.
“A rare morning,” she said with a smile. “I thought I’d try living like an ordinary person, just for once.”
“Even heroes take days off?” I chuckled.
“Sometimes we must,” she replied, sitting beside me and gazing at the children across the square. “Otherwise, we forget who we are.”
We went to the bakery by the gate. The old shopkeeper paused when he saw her, then smiled and handed her two sweet buns. “For saving my grandson last time. I never got to thank you properly.”
“Then I’ll take them today,” she said with a grin, handing one to me.
“I didn’t save anyone.”
“But you’re sharing breakfast with me.”
The bun was almost too sweet, yet it carried a strange comfort. The sunlight caught on her eyelashes, glinting softly. In that moment, she looked less like a warrior—and more like a traveler.
“If there were no monsters,” I asked suddenly, “would you stay here?”
She paused, fingers brushing the edge of the paper bag. “I’ve thought about that. But I don’t belong here.”
“By ‘here,’ you mean this town—or this world?”
She smiled faintly after a moment of silence. “Maybe… time itself.”

We left the bakery. The chimes above the door sang in the wind; children chased pigeons down the street. She stopped briefly at a flower stand, eyes lingering on a bouquet of white hyacinths—then shook her head.
“I used to like flowers,” she said softly. “But now, every time I see them bloom, I think—they all live longer than I do.”
“Don’t say that.”
“It’s just the truth.” She smiled again. “But today, I want to pretend I still believe—I’m alive.”
Her voice was so quiet, as if afraid to disturb the tenderness of the moment. I said nothing—just walked beside her in silence.
The bell from the square rang in the distance. She looked up at the sky, then adjusted her cloak lightly.
“I’m going to check the barrier at the north gate.”
“Now?”
“Just to make sure.” Her expression turned serious. “Listen—tonight, no matter what happens, don’t go outside.”
“Why?”
She didn’t answer. Instead, she lifted her hand and traced a faint mark in the air before my chest. A shimmer of light hung there, like dust caught in sunlight.
“A charm,” she said with a smile. “It’ll grant you one night of dreamless sleep.”
She picked up her basket and disappeared into the crowd. Her silver hair glimmered in the sunlight until it vanished at the far end of the market.
The wind shifted from the north, carrying a chill that didn’t belong. The fountain’s water suddenly arced higher than usual.
I looked up. The sky was clear—yet a faint dark shape flickered briefly among the clouds.
A shiver crawled down my spine. But then the laughter of children and the merchants’ shouts swallowed everything again. The sunlight remained gentle.
I let out a slow breath, but the feeling lingered—that something was quietly drawing near.
